This is because whenever P is true, Q is true based on the original implication, and adding R does not change the truth value of Q when P is true. Specifically, if P ∧ R is true, then P is true, and from P → Q, Q must be true. Therefore, the inference from P → Q to (P ∧ R) → Q is logically valid, regardless of the content of R.
